Location.name: Church's quiet hallway
Location.description: Lined with stained glass that casts colorful patterns on the floor.

Dialogue.speaker: Epictetus
Dialogue.line: There is a certain peace in accepting what is within our power and what is not, wouldn’t you agree?

Dialogue.speaker: Uncle Chip
Dialogue.line: That’s the way of the world. Can’t control much, but we can control how we react to it.

Dialogue.speaker: Epictetus
Dialogue.line: Precisely. Your stories, the way you share them — there's a sense of stoic wisdom in them. A recognition of life’s struggles but also a guide on how to endure.

Dialogue.speaker: Uncle Chip
Dialogue.line: Life in Appalachia teaches you a bit about endurance. And humor too. Can’t get through the day without a good laugh.

Dialogue.speaker: Epictetus
Dialogue.line: Indeed. Laughter in the face of adversity, kinship in times of struggle, and humility in all things — these are the marks of true resilience and virtue.

Dialogue.speaker: Uncle Chip
Dialogue.line: Just living my life, trying to be good to others. Tradition holds us together, gives us something to lean on.

Reflection.comment: Epictetus would see in Uncle Chip not just a custodian but a sage of sorts, practicing the ancient virtues of stoicism through his kinship, resilience, humor, and humility. His stories, rich with tradition, demonstrate a deep understanding of what truly matters in life.
